body: Thanks for reviewing @kevin-bates, merging if there are no more comments
:cake:
@chipsenkbeil Looks like build passes clean now, any other issues, could someone take a quick look at this ?

@lresende, I don't see a problem with shading those jars. I know that `org.clapper.classutil` is only used for our local plugin system. I think `org.objectweb.asm` is a dependency of it, but maybe something else is also bringing it in? Otherwise, just shading the first would be fine, right?

I believe we need both, particularly because folks that were having this issue in CDH for example (see [TOREE-355](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-355)) were suggesting a change to manually shade the `org.objectweb.asm`

`echo 'rule org.objectweb.asm.** org.apache.toree.shadow.@0' >relocate.rules`
`java -jar jarjar-1.4.jar process relocate.rules toree.jar toree-relocated.jar`

And I believe I also had issues with the `org.clapper.classutil` in IOP, particularly when launching in yarn cluster mode.
Yeah basically if you use cloudera spark / hive on the class path this will bite you. Looks good to me

Welcome @kamir! Thanks for finding this bug and working on a fix. Check out this documentation on URL https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/net/URL.html#getFile(), I think a simpler fix is to just change the "getFile" part above to "getPath"

I haven't been able to get the Ivy XML done yet -- sorry for the delay. I was able to generate it in the latest WIP commit, but I wasn't able to generate it at the right stage in the build where we can include it in the Jars. Maybe that's okay and we just need to include the XML in the final assembly Jar?

I also found that gradle doesn't have default support for scalatest, so I'll have to add that as well.

@liukun1016 
In Apache projects' GitHub mirrors, it is unfortunately not possible for maintainers to edit a pull request inline (or commit directly to GitHub either). Could you fix the style issues yourself? The general rule is 2 spaces per indentation depth.
merged, thanks!

I'm still hitting this problem. I pulled the toree master branch & built then installed the pip package in dist/ folder. 

I'm connecting to an yarn cluster in the pyspark kernel.

Using cloudbreak/ambari which is deploying:
- Amazon Linux AMI release 2016.09
- HDP 2.6 
- openJDK 1.8

@olds463 Are you having the same exception with the same classes ? or a different one ? If a different one, could you please open a new jira, otherwise reopen and update the current one. 

BTW, I have tested with Ambari and IOP 4.3 distribution.
yes same issue... I added log output into the toree-355 jira issue. I can't change the status of it.


What is a good test case to verify that it prevents Coursier from downloading the Toree Jars?

I also updated the build to match the current sbt dependencies, run tests, and work with the latest gradle, 3.5. My timed runs before evidently didn't include running tests, so I'm not sure if this is actually much faster than sbt. Still, I think the gradle build is useful.
@mariusvniekerk, I fixed the scala tests, but now I have failures in Python. Any idea what those are? There's not much information to go on.

So I suspect what's happening here is that the integration test is picking up the notification when starting up spark. 

You probably want to adjust the test handler so that you filter out all the non-`execute_result` messages.

@mariusvniekerk, if I run the system-test locally from the commit where this branched, 6997e4d4e622e0af39e60f69417a4fe512b1b10c, I get the same test failures. I don't think they are related to this patch.

Also, we don't control those tests because they are based on [jupyter/jupyter_kernel_test](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_kernel_test/blob/309feed1670140bfd596ebde8bfc12e945a7199c/jupyter_kernel_test/__init__.py). I'll try rebasing this on master to see if that helps.
So we do pretty heavily adjust the kernel test pieces. I assume we are just getting messages in a different order.
@rdblue On your side, is there any pending things for this PR  ? Are we just waiting on the build issue ?

Python tests are failing, but I haven't had time to really find out what's going on. I'm not sure that the test failures are caused by this patch... but I don't think we should commit it until those problems are solved.
@lresende, thanks! I recently found something similar (if not the same problem) in our deployment and added a work-around, so it makes sense... I'll make some time this week to get this updated.

@lresende, you were right. The problem was the notification when getting a Spark context. I updated the code to only send that notification when not running Spark in local mode, when starting a Spark context is quicker because you don't wait on a resource allocator. That fixes the tests.

Thanks for the help, @mariusvniekerk and @lresende! Think this is ready now?

@mariusvniekerk, @jodersky, @kevin-bates, I've cleaned up this PR and I think it is ready to start reviewing.

The major changes are:

1. Interpreters output Map[String, String] so they can send more than just text.
2. Magics also produce Map[String, String]
3. There is no longer a need for a magic PostProcessor, so it has been removed
4. This uses `jupyter.Displayers` to show Scala objects and registers some methods for Spark

More about Jupyter displayers here: https://github.com/jupyter/jvm-repr

Thanks a lot for this.  Could we include a few sample built in mimetypes?  Might be handy for building out some tests.

Maybe displaying a Jackson Json object as `('application/json' -> '{"something": ... }'`
Hurrah!
Good idea. I'll add some tests for the DF output functions, which produce both HTML and plain text.
@mariusvniekerk, I added a few tests in JVMReprSpec and got the rest of them working. Thanks for taking a look at this!
Wrong issue ID, I'm closing this and resubmitting one for TOREE-408.
Looks like the tests for this one conflict with changes in #104. I'll update this once that one is merged.
How to know the reason for the failure of the test? The details said 1 Test Failed for `org.apache.toree.magic.builtin.AddJarSpec` but no further explanations.
@liukun1016 It's a bit further up, [line 3324](https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-toree/builds/241601768#L3324).

@chipsenkbeil, I've updated this and opened the follow-up issues. If you think it is ready, I'll commit it.

I've not committed anything before. What is normal? I'd normally squash the commits first.

@rdblue, sure, go ahead. Normally, we would ask the owner of the PR to rebase first to have a clean merge, which allows the ASF bot to mark the PR as merged. If that's not possible, we would rebase and amend the last commit to close the PR. Squashing was optional, but I'm perfectly fine doing that to clean up the commits.

Merged! It was already based on the current master and I squashed the commits. Thanks for your help here.

I forgot to add the comment to close this, so I'll just do it manually.
LGTM

This is something we had planned to do a long time ago using the `SparkContext.setJobGroup` where each block of code being executed would set a new job group. I'm not sure what the ramifications of setting job groups over and over would be on Spark at this point.

Should this be a configurable option when starting the kernel? Have either a) interrupt kill all Spark work, b) interrupt kill the last Spark job, or c) interrupt only stop current local code execution.

Spark's `setJobGroup` just sets an inherited variable in thread-local context. It should be safe to call multiple times to track jobs started by threads reliably. I don't think we need to do that just yet, since we currently don't have concurrent cell execution. The only way users would accidentally kill Spark jobs is if they were opting to add threads and sent an interrupt. I think it would be reasonable to put off the 100% solution in favor of the 80% one right now, since the current behavior where we don't cancel anything is worse. Still, if you think the 100% solution is important we can probably get that done without too much trouble.

Rebased on master and fixed the test failure.

The problem was with the test itself. The addJar code was returning the file name based on a query param instead of the URL's path. Since query params can be in any order and can't be relied upon for correct file names, the right thing to do is to get the filename from the path component. I updated the test to do that.
Rebased and fixed tests. I think this is good to go.
@kamir, I think this fixes #118 because URI correctly parses the file name without query params. Can you have a look?
I'm able to run the failing test locally with `make system-test` and it passes, any idea why it would fail on the CI build?

I pulled in the interpreter changes which solved an issue where I would get:
```
 found: org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.SparkContext'
required: org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.org.apache.spark.SparkContext'
```
After running the AddDeps magic.  Thanks for this! Good work

@kalvinnchau, that was fixed by "Fix kernel references after %AddDeps." The problem was that the interpreter was redefining the classes, but using the old reference. Rebinding everything after changing dependencies is what fixes it. Glad it is working for you.

I think that might be a flaky test. Can you close and reopen to kick off tests again?

Also, what error message were you seeing that is fixed by this? I've seen a few `Predef` problems that might be fixed, but I'm not sure.

@rdblue The main error was `object Predef does not have a member classOf` it would only happen when the dependency on org.scala-lang.modules (which isn't covered in the exclusion)

The kafka libraries were perfect to test this `org.apache.kafka kafka_2.10/2.11` because 2.10 didn't include the modules package and that always succeeded, where the 2.11 would always fail

@kalvinnchau, Does applying this PR have any effect on the problem you just posted? That's really strange.
@rdblue applying this PR allowed me to get that far :) haha
@chipsenkbeil may have an idea what is happening.

Couldn't tell you without diving deeper. I believe we are executing line-by-line when submitting code cells; so, I'm not sure why including it fixes that. @rdblue, none of your PRs changed our code execution behavior, did they? If we were bundling multiple lines together, it could affect the result based on how Scala's REPL generates the code to be evaluated.

I did change the behavior to evaluate blocks instead of individual lines: https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/commit/5cd1727089eff26f553f990ab9dfe49d2be14fe2#diff-1008ba2d7bf6341cdaf51008230245c5R165.

That change handles the return value of a block as the object to display. It also avoids calling the compiler multiple times and, I think, handles cases slightly better where a statement appears to be complete but isn't (e.g., method chaining). What is the rationale for interpreting line-by-line?

When invoking line magics, we wanted to support you having `%AddJar` in the same cell as code that depended on the jar. With the line-by-line evaluation, the code would work as it would invoke the `%AddJar` separately from the latter code. When evaluating all code at once, it would fail because it could not compile the cell as the needed jar for the compile and runtime requirements had yet to be downloaded.

It's a minor case and I agree that cell-based evaluation feels a little more stable.

The tests caught the line magic issue. I think since those are already parsed out of the cell, we can handle it as a special case. I already want to avoid the sending all magic execution through the Scala interpreter, so we can fix %AddDeps when we fix that.

Calling magics directly will allow for better interaction with interpreters that are wrapped by magic. For example, the SQL interpreter can't use magics at all right now, and %%sql can't use the SQL interpreter's isComplete logic.
Agreed. I had wanted to move magics out of the interpreter route, but it wasn't a high enough priority at the time.
Is it safe to just not pin this on the upper side @rgbkrk
I'd only pin `>= 4.0`.
`jupyter_core` has its own versioning separate from `jupyter_client` by the way -- the last release was `4.3.0`.

I had tried just pinning the lower version but thought there was some specific reason for pinning the higher version as well. But I agree that pining just the lower version should be ok and will make this simpler. I have updated the pr with the suggestions.
Seems to just be dying due to the travis no-space-left on device issue?
Yes, I will merge this if there are no more comments, I have also sent an e-mail to the dev list about the build space issue.
@rdblue  Could you take a look at this, thanks
LGTM, merging if there are no more comments.
LGTM, Also agree with the 80% solution for now. Merging if there are no more comments.

The simplest way from a client side would be to just force the initialization.  

 Yarn cluster is kind of a strange mode for an interactive repl to be running under.  I'm not sure how crucial this particular run mode is given that yarn-client is a much more natural mode for this to be running under. 

It feels to me like we should document the behavior under yarn-cluster and I guess if they exist mesos-cluster and k8n-cluster saying that whilst it will behave it is unsuitable for an interactive repl for most users. 

_Sent from my Google Pixel using [FastHub](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.fastaccess.github)_

Agree with @lbustelo here.  We should get this in.

LGTM! 

_Sent from my Google Pixel using [FastHub](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.fastaccess.github)_

I don't think it is a good idea to add an option for lazy or eager initialization. Lazy initialization is better for usability because you can configure the context and don't have to wait for it to start up before connecting. The only time you would want eager initialization is when the context has to start or else Spark thinks the application is dead when running it in the AM. Maybe we could remove that check or make the timeout large enough that it doesn't matter.

There is a good argument for running initialization after the rest of the bootstrap actions are done and the kernel is accepting connections. That way Toree is as responsive as possible.

LGTM!

_Sent from Disneyland_
We were able to get current Toree working with lazy initiation in Yarn Cluster mode, and thus this pr is not required.
@lresende, how did you get lazy initialization working? Did you disable the check in the Spark AM?
Thanks for reviewing, @mariusvniekerk! I rebased and will merge after tests pass.

> Did you disable the check in the Spark AM?

@rdblue -- increasing the `spark.yarn.am.waitTime` to `1d` was sufficient to effectively _"disable the check in the Spark AM"_
@ckadner, thanks! We're going to be testing out running Toree in cluster mode soon, so I'm interested in any tips like this you guys have.
